Banquet Features Shaffer,
Highlights Parents' Visit
Dean G. Wilson Shaffer will
be the principal speaker at the
banquet which highlights this
year's Parents' Day. The banquet will be held In Levering
Cafeteria at 6:30 p.m., Saturday.
May 7, and according to Al Nogen, co-chairman of the day,"At
least 350 people are expected."
Parents' Day will not officially begin until 10:00 Saturday
morning when the parents sign
in at Levering Hall. However,
for early arrivals there is the
IFC sing in Levering Great Hall
at 6 p.m., Friday.
the

Following
parents will be taken on campus
tours conducted by members of
the Student Council, the ODK,
and the Booster Club.
At 12 noon a lunch will be
served to the parents in the
dormitory snack.bar. At the lacro.sse game a special section has

been reserved in the stands for
the parents participating.
Following the game will be the
banquet at which Dr. Willis
Gore will act as toastmaster.
For those parents who wish to
stay, in the evening there is the
Annual Glee Club Concert. An
innovation in this year's program will be an information
booth in Levering Hall YMCA at
which either Al Nogen or Mace
Mayasaki will be in constant attendance.
Al Nogen has stated: "According to all indications this
year's Parents Day promises to
be one of the most successful
ever. We are very pleased with
the response of the parents and
envision a truly exciting day. We
also would like to thank the
Alumni Association, Dean Morrill, Levering Hall, and especially Dr. Eisenhower for their cooperation."

Swarthmore President
Dr. Nason has been president
of the Foreign Policy Association, a national organization devoted to the study of foreign
relations, since 1953. He previously served as president of Swarthmore College from 1940.
He was graduated from Carleton College in Minnesota hi 1926,
studied at Yale Divinity School
in 1926-27, earned an M.A. from
Harvard in 1928 and that same
year was awarded a Rhodes
Scholarship. In 1931 he earned
a second BA. from Oriel College, University of Oxford, England, and subsequently has been
honorary

CAMPUS POLITICAL ASSEMBLY
PRESENTS PARTY PLATFORMS
The Young Democrats and Young Republicans Clubs presented campaign platforms at a
political assembly at 10:00 a.m. today in Shriver Hall. The assembly, sponsored by the Student
Council in conjunction with the two campus political organizations, marks the 1960 nationwide
presidential campaigns.
Pat Connolly, in behalf of the Young Republicans, and Barry Miller, speaking for the
Young Democrats, presented platforms on national security, human rights, education, economic
growth and the farm situation.
After the assembly, which was arranged mainly through the efforts of Bill Brandon, Dave
Ricci and Bill DeVoe, ebospherated students expressed their political sentiments by casting ballots in ballot boxes located in the lobby of Shriven Alpha Phi Omega, the national service fraternity, counted the votes.
Below are summaries of the platforms of the two political clubs as presented this morning.

Republicans

Democrats

The members of the Young
Republicans Club of the Johns
Hopkins University, wish to reassert their faith in the philosophy of the Republican Party
and the principles which that
party forwards.
They believe that Republicanism is solidly grounded on traditional American political philosophy, the Republican Party
abhors centralization of power,
and has consistently made a studied effort to
build up the strength of state and local government; it firmly adheres to the balance of
power and checks and balances theory of American government.
It views private enterprise as a force for the
good and believes that regulation of such enterprise can only be condoned when the welfare
of the whole is threatened. It firmly holds that
inflation is detrimental to sound economic
growth, and that price, wage, and material controls are justified only in times of severe dislocation due to war emergency.
It holds that labor and management are now
on approximately equal bargaining terms, and
that government interference only tends to postpone bona fide bargaining. The two Republican Administrations of President Eisenhower
have seen no loss of territory or principle to
the United States and the Free World, the unleashing of our economy from arbitrary governmental controls, the encouragement of free,
private enterprise which has raised America to
the highest standards of prosperity.
They hold that the present Republican Administration has proven itself more than capable of assuming leadership of a world threatened by totalitarian Communism; critics of the
present administration have labeled it a "do
nothing" administration, but never before have
peoples in foreign lands given a head of state a
more enthusiastic acclamation than that given
to Dwight D. Eisenhower as he rallied the
strength of the Free World behind American
leadership.
The Young Republicans firmly hold that
America's leadership of the Free World can
only be maintained by a reelection of a Republican Administration dedicated to protecting
human rights, dignity, and honor in a world
made stronger by America's selfless leadership.

The Young Democrats' platform has been described as one
of "constructive protest against
the aimlessness and apathy of
the Republicm Administration."
The national security plant criticizes the Eisenhower administration for "tuiduly compromis9 ing America's former unquestioned military superiority."
The club advocates increased
mobility of the armed forces, an
increased reserve and effective unification of
the armed forces.
The platform calls on the administration to
recapture the diplomatic lead by proposing
"bold and creative programs for the peaceful
international administration of outer space,"
by increasing aid to underdeveloped countries
with increased emphasis on the emerging African states.

The Inter-Fraternity Council
spent a full meeting last week
discussing, planning, and finally deciding on the formula to be
followed by all fraternities at
Hopkins in next year's rush season.

In the field of civil rights, the Young Democrats support the Dixon bill currently before
the Baltimore City Council, prohibiting racial
discrimination in public and private housing and
in hotels and restaurants. They advocate the
establishment of a Federal Fair Employment
Practices Commission, the enactment of a federal anti-lynching bill, federal aid to schools
involved in desegregation, holding back aid to
colleges and universities which discriminate in
admissions on the basis of race, creed or national origins.

Having previously reached an
agreement on the length of the
official rush season, planned to
be two-and-one-half weeks long,
the IFC delegates set upon the
task of deciding just what wouLd
take place during that period.

They call on President Eisenhower to endorse
the Supreme Court decision of desegregating the
public schools. The platform also calls for a
massive program of federal aid to education and
the repeal of the loyalty oath on National Defense Loans.
Other planks include a program to drastically reduce farm surpluses and extension of
social security benefits to mtdical insurance.

Dr. Milton S. Eisenhower
commenting on WUS has stated:
"For forty years the World
University Service has operated
on the premise that the hundreds of millions of students
throughout the world are joined
together by a devotion to learning which transcends barriers
of nationality, language, and
geography. It has distributed
urgently needed aid in times of
crisis and catastrophe, and it
has also formulated programs of
self-help whereby students in
many different countries have
been encouraged and taught how
to help themselves. At a time
when the process of education
itself demands an ever increa,sing awareness of America's international responsibilities, I can
think of few organizations more
worthy of the support of the
Johns Hopkins community than
the World University Service."

The events of the weekends

night. While a number of
thoughts were expressed as to
the imbalance of this set-up,
most felt that it would work out
well.
Second Weekend
For the second weekend, seven
invitation parties will take place
one night and seven others on
the following night.
When discussion began conthird weekend,
cerning the
many fraternities expressed concern over having an invitation
party on Friday eve for all fraternities, and then having open
houses on Saturday night. Many
felt that the proverbial 'last
open house' was only a last ditch

opportunity for some fraternities to get freshmen drunk, and
use all sorts of devious means to
keep them in their houses and
try to get them to change their
minds.
The outcome of the discussion
was that, by a vote of 17-6, the
fraternities will hold one invitation party on the last Friday
night, and then have Saturday
as the day for freshmen to sign
up for fraternities, similar to

Goucher Damsels
Go To Work Here

Fifty Goucher damsels have

to raise money. (Read on!)
To gain funds in support of

Dr. Sachs Comments
Dr. Sachs commented upon the
uniqueness of Baltimore in racial
problems. Although considered
to have a southern "white" attitude on discrimination. Baltimore has an articulate Negro
leadership such as usually found
in the North.
Twenty years ago Jim Crow
was legalized on certain railways
and boat lines of Maryland by
state law. Downtown department
stores did not sell to Negroes.
With the exception of the transit
system, every other service was
segregated.
The initial breakdown to this
pattern of discrimination was
begun legally. There being no

To a newspaperman stepping into the shoes of editorin-chief goes a responsibility far greater than just gadabout, jack-of-all-trades, general coordinator and chief
story-writer. When it comes down to bare type, we feel
that it is 'responsibility number one' for an editor-in-chief
to be able to speak up, here in this column, on the problems, decisions, and actions befronting the sphere of influence of his newspaper. There is no community anywhere that would not benefit by an enlightenment of its
problems, and Hopkins is certainly no exception.
Situations will be created that will demand a prompt
and thorough airing—the editorial column thrives on
them.
Let it then be the understanding of all that the NewsLetter will, as always, be the everwatchful watchdog, seeking to help its community, the organizations in it, and the
people who comprise it, create it, and run it.

Fagin Talks Of fhekhov
Shriver Hall was the scene, last Sunday evening, of the final Amos Taylor, Jr. Memorial Lecture in this year's series, sponsored by the
Johns Hopkins Playshop. A moderately large
assemblage heard Dr. N. Bryllion Fagin, associate professor of English and Drama at this
university on the topic: Chekhov, the Dramatist, 1860-1960. Dr. Fagin is former director of
the Johns Hopkins Playshop where in the past
he has directed several of the plays of Anton
Chekhov for presentation to the Hopkins community. Currently, Dr. Fagin is engaged in work
on a book on Chekhov. His affinity for his subject and his devotion to it were plainly evident.
Talking about Chekhov is, for Dr. Fagin, a
"labor of love".
Dr. Fagin chose to begin his remarks by discussing a movement in modern literary criticism, the so-called "New Criticism", in which
any consideration of the man is removed from
any consideration of his works. For a correct
view of Chekhov, Dr. Fagin feels that the man
and his works are inseparable. Chekhov was a
great human being as well as a good writer. His
work reflects the writer and shows the kind of
person he was. Chekhov "loved" his characters
and painted them with warmth and understanding. And the quality of the mind and genius of
Chekhov, said Dr. Fagin, can be seen resident
within his works.
By means of a brief biographical sketch of
Chekhov Dr. Fagin attempted to show how
events in Chekhov's own life and times, when
transferred to bis plays, were accurately and
sympathetically portrayed. In his works, Chekhov could combine compassion as well as subjectivity. In formulating a new type of shortstory writing, which portrayed pathos which
was not sentimental, the lecturer pointed to

Chekhov's influence in this respect upon such
well-known literary figures as Katherine Masefield, D. H. Lawrence, and Franz Kafka.
In the 1890's Chekhov's play The Sea-Gull
opened, only to be hooted-off the stage a failure.
But in 1897 with the formation of the noncommercial Moscow Art Theatre by Stanislavsky and Danchenko, Chekhov had a proper
showcase for his talents. This play literally
"made" the Moscow Art Theatre and ChekhoV
as a playwright. To this day, the emblem of the
Moscow Art Theatre is a sea-gull. (It is interesting to note a somewhat parallel situation
in the case of Eugene O'Neill, who found the
"special showcase" for the display of his talents
in the Provincetown Players, where many of
O'Neill's early plays were first produced.)
Chekhov (like O'Neill) had no "slickness" of
style, and could not be termed a "technician".
He wrote a new type of tragi-comedy. He foresook Aristotle's dictum that a play is action,
in favor of emphasizing the fact that, in life,
nothing happens. By means of his poetry and lyricism he could effectively dramatize this. He also
saw the ridiculousness of futile hopes and built
comedy around those observations. In viewing
Chekhov, what is observed is a great spirit who
infused his writing with his love of mankind.
Following Dr. Fagin's lecture, several members of the Johns Hopkins Playshop Association
presented readings from three Chekhov works;
The Sea-Gull, The Evils of Tobacco, and Swan
Song. Featured were Richard Hart, Matina
Psoras, Paul Hinrichs, Walter Koehler, and
Roche Dorio. These scenes helped graphically
to illustrate many of the points made about
Chekhov in Dr. Fagin's lecture and were very
astutely selected and directed by Hillary Hinrichs.

A GUIDE FOR THE LOVELESS
Gentlemen, take warning, June is almost upon us—June, the
month of brides. Have you got yours yet? If not, don't despair. You don't have to be rich or handsome to get a girl. All
you have to be is kind, considerate, thoughtful, and obliging—
in short, a gentleman.
For example, don't ever call a girl for a date at the last minute. Always give her plenty of advance notice—like three
months for a coke date, six months for a movie, a year for a
prom, two years for a public execution. This shows the girl that
she is not your second or third choice and also gives her ample
time to select her costume.
And when you ask for a date, do it with a bit of Old World
gallantry. A poem, for instance, is always sure to please a
Young lady, like this.
I think you're cute,
Daphne La France.
I'll put on a suit,
And take you to a dance.
In the unlikely event that you don't know any girls named
Daphne La France, try this:
I think you're cute,
Winifred Jopp.
I'll put on a suit,
And take you to a hop.
In the extremely unlikely event that you don't know a Winifred Jopp either, try this:
I think you're cute,
Isabel Prall.
I'll put on a suit,
And take you to a ball.

Critic Criticized
To the Editors:
I would like to include some
commentaries with respect to the
editorial by P. B. published last
week in the News-Letter.
It would be well to emphasize
that there is some sane, healthy
criticism in it. However, P. B's
solution to the problem turns out
to be a feeble attempt at
cynicism, puerile in fashion, and
therefore devoid of any value
whatsoever.
In the last paragraph P. B.
proposes that "They (The Barnstormers) should not be abolished
entirely"—(I do not know precisely what he means, for you
either abolish an entity completely or do not abolish it at
all)—because "It gives a drama
critic work." I was wondering
to whom he was referring when
he mentions "drama critic." As
of now, I do not know of anyone
in the undergraduate student
body with the talent or the sufficient knowledge of the theatre
to deserve such a title.
Arturo Echavarria

If there is no Isabel Prall, Winifred Jopp, or Daphne La
France on your campus, it is quite obvious why you've had
trouble finding dates all year: you've enrolled in an all-male
school, you old silly!
Next let us take up the question of etiquette once you are
out on a date with Isabel, Winifred, or Daphne. The first thing
You do, naturally, is to offer the young lady a Marlboro. Be
sure, however, to offer her an entire Marlboro—not just a
Marlboro butt. Marlboro butts are good of course, but whole
Marlboros are better. You get an extra inch or two of fine
flavorful tobacco—and I mean flavorful. Do you think flavor
Went out when filters came in? Well, you've got a happy surprise coming when you light a Marlboro. This one really' delivers the goods on flavor, and when you hand Isabel, Winifred,
or Daphne a whole, complete, brand-new Marlboro, she will
know how highly you regard and respect her, and she will grow
Misty and weak with gratitude, which is very important when
You take her out to dinner, because the only kind of coed a
college man can afford to feed is a weak and misty coed. Latest
statistics show that a coed in a normal condition eats one and
a half times her own weight every twelve hours.
At the end of your date with Isabel, Winifred, or Daphne,
make certain to get her home by curfew time. That is gentlemanly. Do not leave her at a bus stop. That is rude. Deliver
her right to her door and, if possible, stop the car when you are
dropping her off.
The next day send a little thank-you note. A poem is best.
Like this:

For a wonderful evening, many thanks,
Isabel, Winifred, or Daphne.
I'll take you out for some more merry pranks

trophy as well as the circulating "J.H.U. Chair."

will be entered: AD, ATO,
Beta, Phi Psi, and Sig Ep.
The sing is being sponsored
by the JHU Glee Club.

CAMPUS POLITICAL ASSEMBLY
PRESENTS PARTY PLATFORMS
The Young Democrats and Young Republicans Clubs presented campaign platforms at a
political assembly at 10:00 a.m. today in Shriver Hall. The assembly, sponsored by the Student
Council in conjunction with the two campus political organizations, marks the 1960 nationwide
presidential campaigns.
Pat Connolly, in behalf of the Young Republicans, and Barry Miller, speaking for the
Young Democrats, presented platforms on national security, human rights, education, economic
growth and the farm situation.
After the assembly, which was arranged mainly through the efforts of Bill Brandon, Dave
Ricci and Bill DeVoe, ebospherated students expressed their political sentiments by casting ballots in ballot boxes located in the lobby of Shriven Alpha Phi Omega, the national service fraternity, counted the votes.
Below are summaries of the platforms of the two political clubs as presented this morning.

Republicans

Democrats

The members of the Young
Republicans Club of the Johns
Hopkins University, wish to reassert their faith in the philosophy of the Republican Party
and the principles which that
party forwards.
They believe that Republicanism is solidly grounded on traditional American political philosophy, the Republican Party
abhors centralization of power,
and has consistently made a studied effort to
build up the strength of state and local government; it firmly adheres to the balance of
power and checks and balances theory of American government.
It views private enterprise as a force for the
good and believes that regulation of such enterprise can only be condoned when the welfare
of the whole is threatened. It firmly holds that
inflation is detrimental to sound economic
growth, and that price, wage, and material controls are justified only in times of severe dislocation due to war emergency.
It holds that labor and management are now
on approximately equal bargaining terms, and
that government interference only tends to postpone bona fide bargaining. The two Republican Administrations of President Eisenhower
have seen no loss of territory or principle to
the United States and the Free World, the unleashing of our economy from arbitrary governmental controls, the encouragement of free,
private enterprise which has raised America to
the highest standards of prosperity.
They hold that the present Republican Administration has proven itself more than capable of assuming leadership of a world threatened by totalitarian Communism; critics of the
present administration have labeled it a "do
nothing" administration, but never before have
peoples in foreign lands given a head of state a
more enthusiastic acclamation than that given
to Dwight D. Eisenhower as he rallied the
strength of the Free World behind American
leadership.
The Young Republicans firmly hold that
America's leadership of the Free World can
only be maintained by a reelection of a Republican Administration dedicated to protecting
human rights, dignity, and honor in a world
made stronger by America's selfless leadership.

The Young Democrats' platform has been described as one
of "constructive protest against
the aimlessness and apathy of
the Republicm Administration."
The national security plant criticizes the Eisenhower administration for "tuiduly compromis9 ing America's former unquestioned military superiority."
The club advocates increased
mobility of the armed forces, an
increased reserve and effective unification of
the armed forces.
The platform calls on the administration to
recapture the diplomatic lead by proposing
"bold and creative programs for the peaceful
international administration of outer space,"
by increasing aid to underdeveloped countries
with increased emphasis on the emerging African states.

To a newspaperman stepping into the shoes of editorin-chief goes a responsibility far greater than just gadabout, jack-of-all-trades, general coordinator and chief
story-writer. When it comes down to bare type, we feel
that it is 'responsibility number one' for an editor-in-chief
to be able to speak up, here in this column, on the problems, decisions, and actions befronting the sphere of influence of his newspaper. There is no community anywhere that would not benefit by an enlightenment of its
problems, and Hopkins is certainly no exception.
Situations will be created that will demand a prompt
and thorough airing—the editorial column thrives on
them.
Let it then be the understanding of all that the NewsLetter will, as always, be the everwatchful watchdog, seeking to help its community, the organizations in it, and the
people who comprise it, create it, and run it.

An Average Proposal

Fagin Talks Of fhekhov
Shriver Hall was the scene, last Sunday evening, of the final Amos Taylor, Jr. Memorial Lecture in this year's series, sponsored by the
Johns Hopkins Playshop. A moderately large
assemblage heard Dr. N. Bryllion Fagin, associate professor of English and Drama at this
university on the topic: Chekhov, the Dramatist, 1860-1960. Dr. Fagin is former director of
the Johns Hopkins Playshop where in the past
he has directed several of the plays of Anton
Chekhov for presentation to the Hopkins community. Currently, Dr. Fagin is engaged in work
on a book on Chekhov. His affinity for his subject and his devotion to it were plainly evident.
Talking about Chekhov is, for Dr. Fagin, a
"labor of love".
Dr. Fagin chose to begin his remarks by discussing a movement in modern literary criticism, the so-called "New Criticism", in which
any consideration of the man is removed from
any consideration of his works. For a correct
view of Chekhov, Dr. Fagin feels that the man
and his works are inseparable. Chekhov was a
great human being as well as a good writer. His
work reflects the writer and shows the kind of
person he was. Chekhov "loved" his characters
and painted them with warmth and understanding. And the quality of the mind and genius of
Chekhov, said Dr. Fagin, can be seen resident
within his works.
By means of a brief biographical sketch of
Chekhov Dr. Fagin attempted to show how
events in Chekhov's own life and times, when
transferred to bis plays, were accurately and
sympathetically portrayed. In his works, Chekhov could combine compassion as well as subjectivity. In formulating a new type of shortstory writing, which portrayed pathos which
was not sentimental, the lecturer pointed to

Chekhov's influence in this respect upon such
well-known literary figures as Katherine Masefield, D. H. Lawrence, and Franz Kafka.
In the 1890's Chekhov's play The Sea-Gull
opened, only to be hooted-off the stage a failure.
But in 1897 with the formation of the noncommercial Moscow Art Theatre by Stanislavsky and Danchenko, Chekhov had a proper
showcase for his talents. This play literally
"made" the Moscow Art Theatre and ChekhoV
as a playwright. To this day, the emblem of the
Moscow Art Theatre is a sea-gull. (It is interesting to note a somewhat parallel situation
in the case of Eugene O'Neill, who found the
"special showcase" for the display of his talents
in the Provincetown Players, where many of
O'Neill's early plays were first produced.)
Chekhov (like O'Neill) had no "slickness" of
style, and could not be termed a "technician".
He wrote a new type of tragi-comedy. He foresook Aristotle's dictum that a play is action,
in favor of emphasizing the fact that, in life,
nothing happens. By means of his poetry and lyricism he could effectively dramatize this. He also
saw the ridiculousness of futile hopes and built
comedy around those observations. In viewing
Chekhov, what is observed is a great spirit who
infused his writing with his love of mankind.
Following Dr. Fagin's lecture, several members of the Johns Hopkins Playshop Association
presented readings from three Chekhov works;
The Sea-Gull, The Evils of Tobacco, and Swan
Song. Featured were Richard Hart, Matina
Psoras, Paul Hinrichs, Walter Koehler, and
Roche Dorio. These scenes helped graphically
to illustrate many of the points made about
Chekhov in Dr. Fagin's lecture and were very
astutely selected and directed by Hillary Hinrichs.

A GUIDE FOR THE LOVELESS
Gentlemen, take warning, June is almost upon us—June, the
month of brides. Have you got yours yet? If not, don't despair. You don't have to be rich or handsome to get a girl. All
you have to be is kind, considerate, thoughtful, and obliging—
in short, a gentleman.
For example, don't ever call a girl for a date at the last minute. Always give her plenty of advance notice—like three
months for a coke date, six months for a movie, a year for a
prom, two years for a public execution. This shows the girl that
she is not your second or third choice and also gives her ample
time to select her costume.
And when you ask for a date, do it with a bit of Old World
gallantry. A poem, for instance, is always sure to please a
Young lady, like this.
I think you're cute,
Daphne La France.
I'll put on a suit,
And take you to a dance.
In the unlikely event that you don't know any girls named
Daphne La France, try this:
I think you're cute,
Winifred Jopp.
I'll put on a suit,
And take you to a hop.
In the extremely unlikely event that you don't know a Winifred Jopp either, try this:
I think you're cute,
Isabel Prall.
I'll put on a suit,
And take you to a ball.

If there is no Isabel Prall, Winifred Jopp, or Daphne La
France on your campus, it is quite obvious why you've had
trouble finding dates all year: you've enrolled in an all-male
school, you old silly!
Next let us take up the question of etiquette once you are
out on a date with Isabel, Winifred, or Daphne. The first thing
You do, naturally, is to offer the young lady a Marlboro. Be
sure, however, to offer her an entire Marlboro—not just a
Marlboro butt. Marlboro butts are good of course, but whole
Marlboros are better. You get an extra inch or two of fine
flavorful tobacco—and I mean flavorful. Do you think flavor
Went out when filters came in? Well, you've got a happy surprise coming when you light a Marlboro. This one really' delivers the goods on flavor, and when you hand Isabel, Winifred,
or Daphne a whole, complete, brand-new Marlboro, she will
know how highly you regard and respect her, and she will grow
Misty and weak with gratitude, which is very important when
You take her out to dinner, because the only kind of coed a
college man can afford to feed is a weak and misty coed. Latest
statistics show that a coed in a normal condition eats one and
a half times her own weight every twelve hours.
At the end of your date with Isabel, Winifred, or Daphne,
make certain to get her home by curfew time. That is gentlemanly. Do not leave her at a bus stop. That is rude. Deliver
her right to her door and, if possible, stop the car when you are
dropping her off.
The next day send a little thank-you note. A poem is best.
Like this:

For a wonderful evening, many thanks,
Isabel, Winifred, or Daphne.
I'll take you out for some more merry pranks

cheerleaders
female

Will make their maiden appearance at the RPI Lacrosse game
tomorrow at Homewood Field.
The girls have been practicing with the male Hopkins
Cheerleaders in preparation for
their debut. Three of the girls
Come from Hampton House,
three from Mercy Hospital, and
one from Mt. Wilson Hospital.
All seven are currently student
nurses and all have had previous cheerleading experience.
New cheers have been written and will be distributed at
the game in honor of this gala
event. Also a special Hopkins
Cheering section will be set
aside for Hopkins students only.
